content.brief: Username and password is not enough to keep your accounts secure – the ‘Lock Down Your Login’ PSA campaign suggests using using strong authentication to help prevent unauthorized access to your accounts and information.

If you believe you or your organization have been the victim of a cybersecurity incident, defined as a violation or imminent threat of violation of computer security policies, acceptable use policies, or standard security practices, please report the incident to National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center (NCCIC) through this reporting form.
If as a result of a cybersecurity incident you believe you are a victim of identity theft, report the incident to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and find steps you can take to recover.

Phishing is defined as an attempt by an individual or group to solicit personal information from unsuspecting users by employing social engineering techniques, typically via emails containing links to fraudulent websites. Follow the instructions found here to submit these email messages to United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team (US-CERT) to help others avoid becoming victims of phishing scams.
If you believe you or your organization is the victim of ransomware, internet fraud, or other cybercrime, file a complaint with the Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) through this form.

articles.title: Report a Cyber Incident as an Industrial Control System (ICS)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: If you have been the victim of ransomware, internet fraud, or other cybercrime, call your local law enforcement personnel and file a complaint with the Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) through this form.

Ready.gov is a national PSA designed to educate and empower Americans to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This resource includes information on what to do before, during, and after a cyber attack.

Pursuant to the Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA), each federal agency is required to notify and consult with US-CERT regarding information security incidents involving the information and information systems. Guidance for these notifications can be found here.

The Federal workforce is the Government’s first line of defense in protecting the People’s information. The desired target state is a culture where every employee recognizes the criticality of protecting the People’s information and their role in cyber risk management.
The People’s information is a priceless asset. The United States Government and its employees must ensure its integrity, confidentiality, and availability are expertly managed.

articles.title: Do the Right Things the Right Way
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Best practices often bring about policy compliance, yet policy compliance does not always deliver best practices. Basic cyber hygiene is the foundation of effective federal cybersecurity.

The most successful organizations are the ones that are constantly challenging their own limitations. Constant innovation and wise investment will allow federal agencies to improve systematically instead of sporadically and unevenly, providing a smoother, more effective path to tighter, secure IT systems.

articles.title: NIST Computer Security Incident Handling Guide
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Recommendations of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) assisting organizations in establishing computer security incident response capabilities and handling incidents efficiently and effectively. This publication provides guidelines for incident handling, particularly for analyzing incident-related data and determining the appropriate response to each incident.

articles.title: Free Security Check Ups and Tools
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Many computer security vendors offer free computer security checks for your computer. This resource includes links to free virus scans, checkups, and other tools to help keep you safe.

The CISO Council seeks to improve and enhance the cybersecurity posture of the United States by providing a government-wide forum that:

  • promoting the identification, development, and promotion of best practices;
  • instilling shared situational awareness and threat identification;
  • developing and promulgating information security policy;
  • improving strategic hiring and training of cybersecurity professionals;
  • encouraging implementation of shared services; and
  • providing professional development for cybersecurity professionals.

Performance.gov is a window to the Administration’s efforts to deliver a more effective, smarter, and leaner government. The site gives the public, agencies, members of Congress, and the media a view of progress underway in cutting waste, streamlining government, and improving performance. The link below directs to the Cybersecurity section of the site, where metrics on agency performance can be viewed.

Improve cybersecurity performance through ongoing awareness of information security, vulnerabilities, and threats impacting the operating information environment, ensuring that only authorized users have access to resources and information; and the implementation of technologies and processes that reduce the risk of malware.

articles.title: Make Informed Cyber Risk Decisions at the Right Level
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: In the past, most cybersecurity decisions were made in the server room. Today’s environment calls for informed decisions to be made at the right levels based on a clearly-articulated risk management construct.

In 2016 we released the first ever Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy directing a series of actions to identify, recruit, develop, retain, and expand the pipeline of the best, brightest, and most diverse cybersecurity talent for Federal service and for our Nation. The strategy brings all levels of government together with private industry, academia, international partners, and the public, to raise the level of cybersecurity in both the public and private sectors; deter and disrupt adversary activities in cyberspace; improve capabilities for incident response and resilience; and enact legislation to both incentivize and remove legal barriers to cybersecurity threat information-sharing among private entities and between the private sector and the Government.
